ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Symmetrical moderate to severe thresholds, normal tympanometry, and acoustic reflexes consistent with cochlear site of lesion.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To establish upper limits for hearing aid output (RESR90).
To identify specific listening goals and assess outcomes.
To verify hearing aid gain and output against prescribed targets.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Results revealed a bilateral symmetrical moderate to severe sensorineural hearing loss with a gradually sloping configuration. Speech recognition thresholds agreed with pure-tone averages, and word recognition scores were good (84%) bilaterally. Tympanometry was normal, and acoustic reflexes were consistent with cochlear involvement, ruling out middle ear or retrocochlear pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral symmetrical moderate to severe SNHL (250-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs 60 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 84% bilaterally (NU-6).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Thresholds and decay indicative of cochlear involvement.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Pre-fitting assessment demonstrated extremely poor unaided audibility (SII 0.02). Fitting verification via Real Ear Measures (REM) showed that the manufacturer's First-Fit significantly underamplified high frequencies. The NAL-NL1 targets were manually corrected for bilateral summation and channel summation (20 channels) to prevent loudness discomfort while ensuring audibility; the final fit matched these corrected targets.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Speech Intelligibility Index (SII) calculated as 0.02 (2% audibility).

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs) measured 500-4000 Hz; patient reported 'loud, but OK'.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: COSI administered to establish goals (female/child voices, TV, noise, telephone).

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Manufacturer First-Fit underamplified highs; final fit matched NAL-NL1 targets corrected for bilateral and channel summation (5-11 dB reduction).

proposed_items: Bilateral hearing aids with 20 channels of signal processing
Verification using Real Ear Measures (REM) with targets corrected for bilateral summation and channel summation
counseling_actions: Explanation of SII and impact of hearing loss on communication (missing 98% of speech cues)
Anatomy and physiology of the ear and hearing loss
Advantages of bilateral amplification (localization, speech in noise)
Realistic expectations using a bar graph (aided vs. unaided in quiet vs. noise)
Discussion of hearing aid styles, technology levels, and costs
Use of telecoil for telephone and assistive technology

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for medical clearance prior to hearing aid fitting, as per clinic protocol.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing aid performance and patient satisfaction.

expected_outcome: Patient reported being very pleased with the performance of the hearing aids and custom earmolds.
Patient reported no problems with loudness.
Aided COSI scores: 'much better' performance for recognizing female and child talkers.
Aided COSI scores: 'much better' performance for recognizing female news reporters on television.
Aided COSI scores: 'much better' performance for speech in noisy listening situations.
Aided COSI scores: 'slightly better' performance for communication on the telephone.
